t: Isaiah 1
The*p vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
Hear,*p O heavens, and give ear, O earth: for the Lord*s hath spoken, I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against me.
The*p ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib: but Israel doth not know, my people doth not consider.

Ah*p sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a seed of evildoers, children that are corrupters: they have forsaken the Lord,*s they have provoked the Holy One of Israel unto anger, they are gone away backward.
Why*p should ye be stricken any more? ye will revolt more and more: the whole head is sick, and the whole heart faint.

From*p the sole of the foot even unto the head there is no soundness in it; but wounds, and bruises, and putrifying sores: they have not been closed, neither bound up, neither mollified with ointment.
Your*p country is desolate, your cities are burned with fire: your land, strangers devour it in your presence, and it is desolate, as overthrown by strangers.
And*p the daughter of Zion is left as a cottage in a vineyard, as a lodge in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city.
Except*p the Lord*s of hosts had left unto us a very small remnant, we should have been as Sodom, and we should have been like unto Gomorrah.
Hear*p the word of the Lord,*s ye rulers of Sodom; give ear unto the law of our God, ye people of Gomorrah.

To*p what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto me? saith the Lord:*s I am full of the burnt offerings of rams, and the fat of fed beasts; and I delight not in the blood of bullocks, or of lambs, or of he goats.
When*p ye come to appear before me, who hath required this at your hand, to tread my courts?
Bring*p no more vain oblations; incense is an abomination unto me; the new moons and sabbaths, the calling of assemblies, I cannot away with; it is iniquity, even the solemn meeting.
Your*p new moons and your appointed feasts my soul hateth: they are a trouble unto me; I am weary to bear them.
And*p when ye spread forth your hands, I will hide mine eyes from you: yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear: your hands are full of blood.
Wash*p you, make you clean; put away the evil of your doings from before mine eyes; cease to do evil;
Learn*p to do well; seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.
Come*p now, and let us reason together, saith the Lord:*s though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
If*p ye be willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the land:
But*p if ye refuse and rebel, ye shall be devoured with the sword: for the mouth of the Lord*s hath spoken it.
How*p is the faithful city become an harlot! it was full of judgment; righteousness lodged in it; but now murderers.
Thy*p silver is become dross, thy wine mixed with water:
Thy*p princes are rebellious, and companions of thieves: every one loveth gifts, and followeth after rewards: they judge not the fatherless, neither doth the cause of the widow come unto them.
Therefore*p saith the Lord, the Lord*s of hosts, the mighty One of Israel, Ah, I will ease me of mine adversaries, and avenge me of mine enemies:
And*p I will turn my hand upon thee, and purely purge away thy dross, and take away all thy tin:
And*p I will restore thy judges as at the first, and thy counsellors as at the beginning: afterward thou shalt be called, The city of righteousness, the faithful city.
Zion*p shall be redeemed with judgment, and her converts with righteousness.
And*p the destruction of the transgressors and of the sinners shall be together, and they that forsake the Lord*s shall be consumed.
For*p they shall be ashamed of the oaks which ye have desired, and ye shall be confounded for the gardens that ye have chosen.
For*p ye shall be as an oak whose leaf fadeth, and as a garden that hath no water.
And*p the strong shall be as tow, and the maker of it as a spark, and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench them.
